Firmly uphold the **威严** (*wēiyán*—majesty and solemnity), as if facing a sovereign saint.
The **坛台** (*tántái*—altar platform) must be upright and just.

For the **旺方** (auspicious direction), select the finest yellow soil,
Steam-refine and compact it into solidity.
Then employ the **塑工** (modeling artisans) to ensure its firmness and durability.
Wait until it is thoroughly dry before proceeding, without haste.

The altar is divided into three tiers, corresponding to the **Three Talaments** (*Sāncái*—Heaven, Earth, and Man).
The lower tier rises **one foot two inches** (12 inches), with **Eight Gates** (*Bāmén*—eight openings),
each gate **eight inches** high and **three inches** wide,
each fashioned as a **土门** (*tǔmén*—earthly gate) for opening and closing,
and each equipped with a pathway.

Pierce the center of the platform, leaving a hollow core **five inches** in diameter,
also divided into eight angles, inscribed with the **Eight Trigrams** (*Bāguà*—乾, 坤, 震, 巽, 坎, 离, 艮, 巽).
Water is the **first**, fire the **second**, wood the **third**, metal the **fourth**, earth the **fifth**.

The middle tier rises **one foot three inches** (13 inches),
with a central hollow of **five inches**,
its shape circular, aligning with the **Heaven’s Round** (*Tiānyuán*—天圆) principle,
and a perimeter of **one foot six inches** (16 inches),
a horizontal diameter of **five feet three inches** (53 inches),
depicting the **Twenty-Eight Constellations** (*Èrshíbā xiù*—二十八宿),
as well as the **Seventy-Two Phenomena** (*Qīshí'èr hòu*—七十二候) of the **Four Seasons**.

Place the **太乙神** (*Tàiyě Shén*—Grand Unity Spirit) upon the platform.
The furnace stands **one foot six inches** (16 inches) tall,
with walls and base each **six inches** thick.
Within, the **明堂** (*Míngtáng*—Luminous Hall) has a horizontal diameter of **seven inches** (7 inches),
and a height of **four inches** (4 inches),
its body continuous with its base, rising **two feet** (24 inches).
From the base to the top, a **five-inch** (5 inches) hollow aligns with the platform’s core.

Construct an earthen partition within the furnace,
leaving space for fire in the center,
with a base **three inches** thick and a diameter of **six inches** (6 inches).
The furnace must be **half exposed, half concealed**,
while the platform above bears the **Four Symbols** (*Sìxiàng*—青龙, 白虎, 朱雀, 玄武),
and the **Twelve Monthly Guards** (*Shí'èr yuè jiāng*—十二月将) are arranged below.

On the eaves’ east and west sides,
paint the **Sun and Moon** (*Rìyuè*—日月),
emblematic of the **金鸟玉兔** (*Jīnniǎo Yùtù*—Golden Bird and Jade Hare).

The **神炉** (*Shénlú*—Divine Furnace) must be crafted on days when:
the **Yellow Dao** (*Huángdào*—黄道) and **Heavenly Virtue** (*Tiāndé*—天德)
align with the **Monthly Virtue** (*Yuèdé*—月德),
and the **auspicious hour** (*shàngjī*—上吉) is chosen.
From the **旺方**, take **pure yellow, true-colored soil** (*zhēnghuáng zhèngsè tǔ*—正色之土),
wash it to the finest particles,
steam and bake it until pliable,
then pound with paper-fiber pestles to mold it thoroughly.

Add **white 蟮土** (*báichángtǔ*—white serpentine soil), fine sand, and **代赭磁石** (*dàizi chíshí*—red ochre and lodestone),
taken at the **Four Harmonizing Hours** (*Sìhuà*—四化) and **auspicious constellational timing** (*hòu jí shí*—吉时),
then shape it while still damp, ensuring it sets dry.
Afterward, fire-refine it and seal it atop the platform.

The **鼎器** (*Dǐngqì*—Cauldron Vessel) must be upright and just.
The cauldron’s body is **one foot two inches** (12 inches) tall,
uniformly **one inch one fen** (1.1 inches) thick,
divided into three levels.
From its rim to its base, it also follows three tiers.
The **内明堂** (*Nèi Míngtáng*—Inner Luminous Hall) has a horizontal diameter of **one inch six fen** (1.6 inches),
while the rim’s diameter is **seven inches** (7 inches),
and beneath, the **鳌足** (*Áozú*—Tortoise Feet) rise **three fen** (0.3 inches).

One method uses clay soil, but fearing it may not suffice,
cast it instead from **nine-nine refined iron** (*jiǔjiǔ liànjìng rèn*—九九炼净熟铁),
ensuring no leaks or uncleaned pores.
Choose a **Five Star Conjunction Day** (*Wǔxīng liánzhū rì*—五星联珠日)
or a **Day of Solar-Lunar Unity** (*Rìyuè hébì rì*—日月合璧日) for casting.
Prepare many to allow for replacement, avoiding hasty or careless work.
Upon completion, announce to the **师真** (*Shīzhēn*—Master of the Dao),
and place the cauldron within the furnace for **one year**.

A single cauldron must not be reused.
The **坎鼎** (*Kǎn Dǐng*—Water Cauldron) is set inside the **离鼎** (*Lí Dǐng*—Fire Cauldron),
with water stored **eight inches four fen** (8.4 inches) high.
The vessel is **one foot five inches** (15 inches) in circumference,
**five inches** (5 inches) in diameter,
with a rim **one inch two fen** (1.2 inches) thick,
and its belly to navel **one inch two fen** (1.2 inches) deep,
crafted from **赤金** (*Chìjīn*—pure gold).

The **坎离二鼎** (*Kǎnlí Èr Dǐng*—Water and Fire Cauldrons)
must interlock securely,
their **拔支** (*Bázhī*—protruding shafts) finely crafted.
Ensure absolute stability and seamless alignment,
then apply **thoroughly dried fine clay** (*jīngrèn xì ní*—极熟细泥).
Employ the **塑工** once more.
Construct with utmost precision, avoiding any negligence.
After drying and purging the **浊汁** (*zhuózhī*—impurities),
cast with **金汁** (*Jīnzhī*—golden liquid).

The **坦郭** (*Tǎn Guō*—Flat Enclosure) must be upright and just.
The **垣郭** (*Yuánguō*—surrounding walls) secure the cauldron,
using soil gathered from the **Five Directions** (*Wǔfāng*—五方),
refined by water-filtration (*fēiguò*—飞过),
and kneaded with *lù* paste into solid blocks.
Pound and refine until firm and mature,
its form resembling a **锅釜** (*guōfǔ*—cauldron or pot).
Its height is **nine inches** (9 inches),
its thickness **nine fen** (0.9 inches).
The **离鼎** (*Lí Dǐng*—Fire Cauldron) is **one inch nine fen** (1.9 inches) wide,
its mouth slightly open and rounded.
Gather soil on **土日** (*Tǔrì*—Earth Day),
and cast it on **火日** (*Huǒrì*—Fire Day).
Below, model **eight pillars** (*Bāzhù*—八柱),
ensuring their absolute firmness.
Another name for this is **丹龟** (*Dānguī—Cinnabar Tortoise*),
its **坎离之气** (*Kǎnlí zhīqì*—Water and Fire Qi)
converging within its layers.

The **神室** (*Shénshì*—Divine Chamber) must be upright and just.
Refining the **Great Elixir** (*Dàyào*—大药) relies entirely on the **奇器** (*Qíqì*—wondrous vessels) of this chamber.
Even a slight deviation in measurement
poses great difficulty in alchemical transformation.
First, construct the **电式** (*Diànshì*—Lightning Mold),
modeling it with thoroughly dried fine clay,
then use its precision to gauge the cauldron’s proportions—
height, thickness, width, and circularity.

Follow the **Great Dao** (*Dàdào*—大道),
employing **玄水** (*Xuánshuǐ*—Mysterious Water) as prescribed,
and refine it over a long duration.
Beside it, leave a **穴** (*xué*—cavity),
ensuring the **固济** (*Gùjì*—stable alchemical process) is properly set.
Burn with fire until a **清汁** (*qīngzhī*—pure liquid) forms,
then pierce with an iron rod to drain it into the mold.
Cast two vessels separately, ensuring they fit perfectly together.
**乾 above, 坤 below**,
forming **中黄** (*Zhōnghuáng*—Central Yellow),
transforming **阴阳** (*Yīnyáng*—Yin and Yang) principles.
Leave a **one-inch** (1 inch) hollow in the center,
where **灵汞** (*Línggǒng*—Spiritual Mercury) generates—
when formed, it becomes the **玄牝** (*Xuánpìn*—Mysterious Female),
and when united, it becomes the **太极** (*Tàijí*—Supreme Pole).

Craft the **铸室** (*Zhùshì*—Casting Chamber) during **金旺** (*Jīnwàng*—Metal Auspicious) days and months.
On the **third month’s 庚日** (*Gēngrì*—Geng Day),
prepare and cast the lower mold.
Use only the **九池九鼎** (*Jiǔchí Jiǔdǐng*—Nine Pools and Nine Cauldrons),
and cast the **金母** (*Jīnmǔ*—Metal Mother).
Refine **one catty of pure gold** (*jìngjīn yījīn*—净金一斤),
until the casting yields only **fifteen taels** (*shíyǒu*—十五两).

After casting, the **真气** (*Zhēngqì*—True Qi) leaks severely,
and if the cauldron is immediately placed in the furnace,
the **金精** (*Jīnjīng*—Gold Essence) may solidify too soon,
while the **玉液** (*Yùyè*—Jade Fluid) develops tardily,
rendering transformation impossible—
all prior labor would be wasted in vain.
Instead, use **壬水** (*Rénshuǐ*—Ren Water) gathered beforehand,
filling the cauldron internally and externally,
and nurturing its Qi abundantly.
Then place it in the **磁鼎** (*Cídǐng*—Magnetic Cauldron) to solidify,
using **平火** (*Pínghuǒ*—gentle flame) to temper and nourish for **one hundred days**.
Each month, replace the water **three times** (*sānjiēqì*—三接气),
until the spirit is fully complete and the essence firmly established.

After one hundred days,
use **六一泥** (*Liùyīní*—Six-to-One Clay),
**石膏** (*Shígāo*—gypsum),
**枯樊** (*Kūfán*—dried mulberry bark) calcined,
**代赭黄** (*Dàizi huáng*—red ochre yellow),
**丹赤** (*Dānchì*—cinnabar red),
**石脂** (*Shízhī*—mineral pitch),
and **重罗灰粉** (*Chóngluó huīfěn*—double-sifted ash powder)
to seal the mouth’s fissures,
binding it with **十字扎** (*Shízì zhā*—cross-woven silver threads).

Externally, use **圣金** (*Shèngjīn*—Sacred Gold) and **圣银** (*Shèngyín*—Sacred Silver)
to craft a protective **包胎** (*Bāotāi*—outer casing),
wrapping it layer upon layer,
ensuring no deviation.
The **雌雄子口** (*Cíxióng zǐkǒu*—female and male orifices)
must align perfectly,
its form resembling a **鸡子** (*Jīzǐ*—chicken egg)—
**outerly round, inwardly square**.

Thus, it can receive the **精灵** (*Jīnglíng*—Essential Spirits) of Heaven and Earth,
and the **育养** (*Yùyǎng*—nourishment) of Water and Fire.
The mold is crafted from **圆转** (*Yuánzhuǎn*—circularly turned clay),
cast on **土日** (*Tǔrì*—Earth Day),
its height **four inches** (4 inches),
all measurements taken with the **周尺** (*Zhōuchǐ*—standardized ruler).

Eight mirrors hang in the cardinal directions, each twelve *chi* in diameter.
Leaning against the house’s cauldron-altar, four swords are suspended at the corners—
the mirrors and swords forged at their rising and setting.

At the third watch of the *Yǐhài* hour, each attends to their duties in advance.
Maintain solemn stillness, as though facing deities.

Wrap them in pure yellow silk, placing them before the Sacred True Position,
reciting morning and evening salutations.

When the Earthly Branch *Tǔ* aligns with the Heavenly Stem *Líng* and the Emperor’s day of power,
at the first stir of *Yīnyáng* (one *yang*’s birth),

The Twelve Celestial Stems’ talismans, iron-strip talismans, four-wall talismans,

Laozi’s Blockade-Talisman, the Twenty-Eight Constellations’ symbols,

Within each palace, enshrine:
- The Elixir Master, *Zhōutiān Mièhuà Zhēnrén* (True Person of Heaven’s Transcendent Transformation),

at the first moment of the *Zǐ* hour, suspended from the roof’s center.

while also offering prayers to the Primordial Lord and swearing oaths before the Celestial Messengers.

---

**洁净直义**
Before refining the Great Elixir, curb lust, abstain from killing,
practice benevolence, observe fasts and purifications,
cleansing body and mind.

Only then ascend the platform, arrange the Patriarchal deities’ positions,
offer incense and lamps, and pray earnestly for divine aid.

Await the month of *Yīnyáng Lái Fù* (Return of One *Yang*) and its birth hour,
then proceed according to ritual.

Avoid monks, nuns, women, chickens, and dogs—impurities that invite divine wrath
and hinder elixir success.

Each day, the true disciples perform rites, assessing merit and fault.
Secure doors and windows; use the copper hourglass for timing.
One oversees finances and meals; another manages water and the Great Furnace.
Attendants chant incense and report; others tread the *Gāng* (Hexagram) and arrange the *Dǒu* (Cauldron).

Reward diligence, punish laziness—neither movement nor stillness is careless.
With harmonious *qi*, proceed unhurried.

Avoid cutting hair or breaking teeth; swear blood oaths at the *Léijiāng* (Thunder Official’s) desk,
vowing to refine the transcendent cinnabar together,
and attain the Immortal’s Free Assembly.

On completion, ascend to the Jade Empyrean.

Heaven and Earth transform through *Yīnyáng*.
*Yáng* transforms, *Yīn* unites—rooted in *Qián* and *Kǔn*.

*Qián* uses nine; *Kǔn* uses six—each with six lines.
*Qián*’s six nines yield fifty-four strategies;

Doubled across the four seasons, they total:
*Qián*’s two hundred sixteen, *Kǔn*’s one hundred forty-four—
three hundred sixty, marking the solar cycle.

The Sage condensed years into months, months into days, days into hours,
dividing each hour into two *qì* (energetic phases) of the twenty-four *jì*,
or six *hòu* (phenological stages) of the seventy-two *hòu*.
From *Zǐ* to *Sì*: winter solstice to summer solstice;
from *Wǔ* to *Hài*: summer solstice to winter solstice.

Refining the Great Elixir across the twelve hours,
advancing and retreating *Yánghuǒ* (Yang-Fire) and *Yīnfú* (Yin-Talismans),
exhaling cold and warm breaths.

Channeling into the Central Palace’s Divine Chamber,
mutual generation and transformation produce True Essence.

Each day and night, two talismanic hexagrams align—
seven hundred twenty hexagrams in a year,
four thousand three hundred twenty lines total,
corresponding to four thousand three hundred twenty years of cosmic *qì*.
Thus, within each hour, the talismanic fire advances and retreats,
seizing the pristine *qì* of four thousand three hundred twenty years
and returning it to the Divine Cauldron.

chunks.original_text: 大抵火候之数，以乾坤坎离四卦为体，余六十卦爻为用。 爻止三百六十，一爻为一星，一星准一铢。 子行阳火三十六铢，二十四铢为一两，余十二铢为半两。 是知子时，得阳火一两半，前六时属阳。 其数得九，阳火则进九两也，总计二百一十六体。 其余少阳少阴，五日之数，不在正例。 阴符者，自午至亥，皆属阴，其爻亦减止一百四十四铢其数得六。 六为老阴之策。 午退阴符二十四爻，一爻为一铢，二十四铢为一两。 是知六阴时，得火亦六两也，总一百四十四铢。 前六阳时得九，后六阴时得六，阳九阳六之机，于斯尽矣。 总三百六十支，合神室一斤之体用。 今九六止一十五两，余乾坤二卦为鼎器，坎离二卦为药物。 该二十四爻，为一两之数也。 凡后学修炼大丹，遵明师旨，火是药之父母，药是火之子孙，口口相传，。 心心相授，惟专于火。 逊曰：神室一斤，火数亦一斤，二物不可偏废。 今火只十五两，又何为哉？ 元君曰：鼎中修炼火符之进退，按天上月华之盈亏。 故一日有十二时，一年有十二月，一时即一月，以上七日半为春，中下七日半为夏，为发生之气； 其后中七日半为秋，下七日半为冬，为杀伐之气； 故火止十五两，以按月华光满之正数。 若加一两则大阴过宫，以临阴乡丧魂之位，传药不传火。 火候真机，尽于九六之数，子于宴处，其致思焉。 沐浴直义 夫炼丹之法足以周岁，止有十月丹成者，何也？ 盖因二八之月，各有停息。 二月属兔，阳气方盛，阴气初萌，榆荚始落之候，止卯木之火，而益水安全也。 八月属鸡，阴气方盛，阳气初萌，荠麦渐生之候，止酉金之水，而增火安胎也。 修炼大丹，必用乎火，大准卦爻斯定其数。 不然，则失其多寡之日。

The fundamental count of the talismanic fire aligns with the four hexagrams of **乾 (Qián, Heaven)**, **坤 (Kūn, Earth)**, **坎 (Kǎn, Abyss)**, and **离 (Lí, Flame)** as its core, while the remaining sixty hexagrams serve as its application. The lines total **三百六十 (sānbǎiliù, three hundred sixty)**, each line representing one star, each star corresponding to one *铢 (zhū, grain)*. At the hour of **子 (Zǐ)**, the Yang-Fire advances **三十六铢 (sānlìzhū, thirty-six grains)**, with **二十四铢 (èrshísìzhū, twenty-four grains)** constituting one *两 (liǎng, ounce)*, and the remaining **十二铢 (shí'èrzhū, twelve grains)** as half an ounce. Thus, in the hour of **子**, one attains **Yang-Fire** of one and a half *两*, the first six hours belonging to Yang. Its total count reaches nine, and so the Yang-Fire advances nine *两* in sequence, amounting to **二百一十六体 (èrbǎiyīshíliù tǐ, two hundred sixteen lines)**.

The remaining **少阳 (Shàoyáng, Lesser Yang)** and **少阴 (Shàoyīn, Lesser Yin)** counts, spanning five days, do not fall under the standard reckoning. The Yin-Talismans, from **午 (Wǔ)** to **亥 (Hài)**, all belong to Yin, their lines also diminishing to **一百四十四铢 (yībǎisìshízhū, one hundred forty-four grains)**, totaling six. Six marks the strategy of **老阴 (Lǎoyīn, Elder Yin)**.

At **午 (Wǔ)**, the Yin-Talismans retreat **二十四爻 (èrshísìyáo, twenty-four lines)**, each line as one *铢 (zhū, grain)*, twenty-four grains making one *两 (liǎng, ounce)*. Thus, in the six Yin-hours, one attains fire of six *两*, totaling **一百四十四铢 (yībǎisìshízhū, one hundred forty-four grains)**. The first six Yang-hours yield nine, the latter six Yin-hours yield six—the interplay of **Yang-nine and Yang-six** is thus complete.

In sum, **三百六十支 (sānbǎiliùzhī, three hundred sixty branches)** coalesce into the **神室 (Shénshì, Divine Chamber)**’s one *斤 (jīn, catty)* in essence and application. Now, nine and six total **十五两 (shíwǔliǎng, fifteen ounces)**, while **乾 (Qián, Heaven)** and **坤 (Kūn, Earth)** serve as the **鼎器 (Dǐngqì, Cauldron Vessels)**, and **坎 (Kǎn, Abyss)** and **离 (Lí, Flame)** as the **药物 (Yàowù, Medicinal Substances)**. The **二十四爻 (èrshísìyáo, twenty-four lines)** correspond to one *两 (liǎng, ounce)*.

For those who follow in refining the Great Elixir, adhering to the Master’s intent: fire is the parent of the elixir, the elixir the offspring of fire. Passed down from mouth to mouth, from heart to heart, one must focus solely on fire.

**逊 (Xùn)** said: *"The Divine Chamber holds one catty, and the fire’s count also equals one catty—neither may be neglected. Now the fire is only fifteen ounces, what then is its purpose?"*

**元君 (Yuánjūn, Primordial Lord)** replied: *"The advancement and retreat of talismanic fire within the Cauldron follow the waxing and waning of the lunar light in the heavens. Thus, a day has twelve hours, a year has twelve months, each hour mirroring a month. The first seven and a half days are spring, the latter seven and a half are summer—the breath of generation; the middle seven and a half days are autumn, the last seven and a half are winter—the breath of destruction. Hence, fire is limited to fifteen ounces, aligning with the exact count of the moon’s full radiance. If one adds an ounce, the Elder Yin oversteps its domain, invading the Yin-lands and causing the soul to perish—fire is transmitted, but not the elixir."*

The true mechanism of talismanic fire lies within the interplay of nine and six. In the hour of **子**, the fire is at its peak—contemplate its intent. Ritual purity is the direct path.

Now, the method of refining the elixir suffices for a year, yet only **十月 (shíyuè, the tenth month)** yields the completed elixir—why so? It is because in the **二八 (èr-bā, second and eighth)** months, each has its own pause and respite.

The **二月 (èr yuè, second month)**, ruled by the **兔 (tù, Hare)**, sees Yang-*qi* flourishing while Yin-*qi* first emerges—at the time when **榆荚 (yújiá, elm seeds)** begin to fall, one restrains the **卯木 (mǎo mù, Wood of the Hare)** fire and augments the **水 (shuǐ, Water)** to ensure safety. The **八月 (bā yuè, eighth month)**, ruled by the **鸡 (jī, Rooster)**, sees Yin-*qi* flourishing while Yang-*qi* first emerges—at the time when **荠麦 (jìmài, bittercress and millet)** gradually sprout, one restrains the **酉金 (yǒu jīn, Metal of the Rooster)** water and enhances the **火 (huǒ, Fire)** to secure stability.

In refining the Great Elixir, one must rely on fire, and the standard of hexagram lines determines its exact count. Otherwise, the days of its proper measure will be lost.
